In this article I also write about human metaprograms (programs that instruct you to edit the program itself). The idea with Metaprograms is to make it really easy for people to create and customize their own programs/guides without dealing with the complexity of the editor.

A post about block types in Methodable. Block types are the "language" underlying Methodable's model of human programs, allowing the user to create complex interactive guides without learning any written syntax:
https://t.co/iBa3hPGBvA

@verlantokyo I've been using the phrase "human-programming language". Something similar to a computer programming language but for delivering natural language instructions to people rather than instructions to a computer.

Other thesis: Most software increases optionality (more buttons, more links), which is good for exploration, but software that limits optionality to the bare minimum required for the task at hand is more conducive to intentional work.

Thesis: Computers are good at doing things for us and bad at helping us do things ourselves. Computers would be better equipped to help us do things ourselves if we had a strict language for describing our desired actions to the computer.

@johnnulls I’ve always wanted an outliner with smooth semantic zoom: as you zoom in, hidden blocks pop into existence, child lists uncollapse, blocks become titles and titles become breadcrumbs. You could fix the viewport size and navigate over information like you’re in Google Earth.

And, if you'd like, subscribe to the newsletter to stay up-to-date on the goings-on in human-programming land. I'll be posting further demos and technical notes in upcoming weeks. https://t.co/w6M4lqvLB5

I'm also grateful to @parkerhendo, @ellenchisa and others who supported this project through the https://t.co/ElnJEoVUsB grants program. There's still much to be done before I have a fully online collaborative database of human programs, but I'm working on it! :)

I wrote much of Methodable's code at @recursecenter, and am extremely grateful to the RC community for helping me get this project off the ground, and for being a kind, smart, and supportive group of people.

If you're a self-directed coder who loves learning, check out RC!

I'm excited about human programming because I think it's a largely unexplored aspect of human-computer interaction that can help people in many domains, including learning and teaching, problem solving and planning, workflow documentation/onboarding, and personal routines. https://t.co/btusmFxjjS

So, you can easily switch between a powerful outliner-style editor and a hyper-focused virtual-assistant-style guide.

You can even see both at once by previewing a guide-view of a program as you edit it! https://t.co/wBzYqN8y0t

Methodable stores human programs in a local graph-based data store, and users interact with that data through whatever lens is most optimal for their current use-case (are you editing the program, or following it? If following, what kind of guided experience best suits you?) https://t.co/RIb569opfZ

Methodable aims to be the successor to the how-to guide: a general-purpose tool for creating and following complex workflows, processes and routines.

...so that people are more *able* to be *methodical* (see what I did there?) https://t.co/mbntmTFK52

Optimizing for the interactive workflow comes with problems too. How can I get my beautiful https://t.co/1Kuy0c1syV logic inside an app for users? @_paulshen

A REPL-driven workflow seems to be part of the puzzle. Building UIs makes it default to leave app logic lying around everywhere. By building first in a different medium, you at least have 2 POVs through which you can explore your solution. Also, one of the benefits of TDD.

React has its problems for sure, but are the new breed of frameworks addressing the core issues or just giving us new hoops to jump through? This seems to be the main problem but I don't see any frameworks addressing it https://t.co/bYPc8q8sL9

It's an implementation detail in the grand scheme of tft. But as more tools become web native, JS framework churn takes a toll on developer productivity. All that time could be invested coming up with new media and interaction patterns.
We keep changing frameworks in search for solutions. Are we even addressing the underlying problems that motivated the switch?

In Tana, I currently use:
-> and <- for Progression.
⊂ and ⊃ for Boundaries.
✸/mentions/refs for Time-space association.

When I look at my PKM systems for the last decade, they seem to have revolved around these three main ideas, and that's what I've settled for - for now:
1) Causality/Progression
2) Inclusion-exclusion
3) Contextual-association via time-space

When we "recall events", we don't recall the day itself - we pull up associations of context that happened around the event. Chances are that we've forgotten most of the other context and remembered just 20%.

A "day" is a freeze-frame of the context that are present in that moment of time. Who are the people I met, the places I visited, the news I heard, the ideas I pondered, and so forth. It's like a long-exposure photo summing up the conditions of that particular day.

Certain cultures do not have the same concept of time - The Australian Aborigines have the concept of "circular time", so do many eastern traditions. In that case, we can think of a "particular time" as a snapshot of what context is present at that moment.
Third Axis of Time: Time is a construct. But from the perspective of ideas, it shows relevance to personal and societal context. https://t.co/ohVdARuLEw
This also ties into stereotypes and outliers. Being specific about this forces my mind to contest whether an assumption is true or false.
Hence, I need to define problems and specify definitions precisely. Because if I do not know exactly what I'm trying to solve, how can I solve it? What I measure, I can control.

Why this matters? Well, specificity matters. For example, certain qualia only can be attributed to various phenomena. A ladybug is red, but not all bugs are red. While a ladybug is red, its organs aren't red.

Second Axis of Inclusivity: Any idea can always be subsumed by a more abstract and inclusive idea. For example, tree < forest < land < Earth. At the same time, tree < plants < organisms < life < biology. There is always a way to zoom in or out. An idea is defined by a boundary. https://t.co/Mdka1Eg8q8

But just as we can project possible futures, we can also backwards-rationalise about things. Imo, all outliners function in a way that utilises this to some extent. The problem is - can they extend to "infinite parents", just as they can extend to "infinite children"?
We have synaptic networks that are conditioned in a certain way - therefore, our brains are *literally* geared to work in an if-then manner. i.e. "When this happens, do that."

For example, when you think of the word "yellow", there is a certain tendency that your mind goes towards. It may be a lemon. But there are so many other things that can be associated with yellow - why this particular idea?
First Axis of Causality: Associations aren't random, they have directionality and aren't always bidirectional. Unidirectional progression of ideas create logic. https://t.co/pdEbKajZGH
Just thinking aloud. Was pondering the 3 Axes of my PKM system today, as per: https://t.co/PEGBqLlHqy

With Figma and Miro valued at $20B and $17.5B respectively, and Apple entering the space with Freeform, it feels like infinite canvas is having its moment.

~~ Collaboration ~~

Real-time collaboration enables teams to work exactly the way they want.

~~ Direct manipulation ~~

Freeform movement, editing, and duplication of objects keep the infinite canvas the source of truth.

~~ Zoom ~~

Different zoom levels facilitate navigation, mimicking stepping in and away in the real world.

~~ Expansiveness ~~

A seemingly limitless canvas empowers users to structure documents in their own way.

What makes an infinite canvas?
⬇️

~~ Software that mirrors how we think ~~

Infinite canvas tools embrace the messy, circuitous paths we take when brainstorming, sketching, and distilling ideas. https://t.co/EbTV6XuSeZ

~~ We think spatially ~~

People have been organizing and processing information spatially for centuries, whether by writing in a notebook or posting paper on walls. https://t.co/bFPEjMAyCL

🚀 Infinite canvas: tools that work the way we think.

https://t.co/WC3T966ALE

Regardless of the medium/format of each post-art project, aesthetics are formed through the divergent “thread-pulling”, not the mediums

Musical, literary, artistic, philosophical, other-intellectual genres/-isms, will converge in the same pool of post-art aesthetic systems

Post-art will also acknowledge that, creations are always conversations with what came before

A post-artist (if they ever work alone) is not celebrated as origins of their creations, but as a force pulling together divergent threads (of ideas, visual forms, material cultures…)
It will be kind of like Glass Bead Game, but instead of seeking a universal truth, the post-art’s focus is collective worldmaking & imagination that accommodates pluralities of truth

Nelson Goodman wrote in Ways of Worldmaking that instead of asking “what is art?”, we should ask “when is art?”

One day art will be gone, but imagination & creation will continue. I’d like to think the post-art will be a practice of synthesizing all modes of inquiry

What’s are the core differences between being independent and being individualistic?

It’s simply too easy for a person to write history as if great things happened because of individuals

But studying history of science is much more often about the *environmental & social & political* factors that lead to changes in science. And a great deal of accidents too

so much of the metascience / new science funding talk has been about giving genius individuals unrestrained freedom, presuming that truly innovative ideas come from individual brains. This is very reflective of a “great man theory” of innovation

Which path should you take?
The left doorway has a glowing red light coming from it. The right doorway seems to have some vines growing out of it. https://t.co/47gWa6naOm
You inspect the skeleton and find a rusty axe! It didn't seem to protect these bones, but hopefully it can help you. https://t.co/mYjaOtjUVI

The chamber seems to have the remains of a skeleton in the center and a doorway on either side... You turn around to look at the doorway you came from and all of a sudden a large stone slab falls down and closes your only exit... There's no turning back now.

As you cautiously walk forward you feel a gaping hole in the ground. You catch yourself in-time to navigate around it and not fall into what seems to be a deep pit 💦. A little further you see a glimmer of light that leads you to a lit chamber. https://t.co/8vR1QonNlP

Still in darkness you feel the cool wind coming from within the depths of the hallway. Legend has it that great mysteries are held within, but you ask yourself if it's worth the solo journey into the unknown.
There also are some small rocks and pebbles. You also place this in your bag. It doesn't seem like anything else is nearby. https://t.co/HQSHIKDD6Y

You feel around the floor in darkness and find a mysterious metal object. It looks to be an ancient gear of sorts... You have no idea what it's for, but you place it in your bag. https://t.co/VvqioMpJWU

As you enter the dungeon you have a sense of dread. You have no items on hand and the entrance is pitch black. You can feel a cool breeze coming from the depths of the hallway, but have no idea what's ahead.

Welcome to the dungeon!

In addition to the companies not being located in places we associated with technology, a lot of the university research being done in the area was happening outside of your traditional coastal unis:

University of Arkansas
RPI
University of Tennessee 

etc.

15/

I have yet to verify this, but someone at a company that was doing multimaterial 3D printing claimed that good multimaterial CAD software doesn't exist. 

Seems like a big hole if true.

14/

The idea of a "digital twin" was everywhere -- the idea of a software representation of a part or system that is updated throughout the manufacturing process.

I would just call this "simulation and modeling coupled with measurement" but 🤷‍♂️

13/

There are dominant companies that people at the show talk about the way folks in tech talk about Google or Microsoft that I'd never heard of:

Hexagon
Fanuc

etc.

12/

A few more after going through my notes ...

The structure of the industry is fascinating: machining primarily revolves around small shops. 

There are ~70,000 of them in the US, which feels small when you think about the market for any specific machine being a fraction of that.

@QuantBro They seemed to be headquartered in places like Indiana, Minnesota , and Kentucky — or not in the US. So yes, middle of the country. Same with many of the customers.

CNC user interfaces seem horrible. I'm sure for people who have used them for years they're great, but I suspect there are better ways to do this.

A+ for lots of physical buttons though. 

10/ https://t.co/VndFizXQvH

The demographics were, as you might suspect, very different from either academia or tech: the sales reps skewed towards the grey and (there's no way to put it delicately) most people I saw would look very out of place in coastal metropolitan areas.

9/

Manufacturing is perceived as a slow, crusty industry, but it feels like big companies in this world actually innovate on their core products far more than the Googles and even Apples of the world. 

Likely because their business model is: you give me money, I give you thing

on personal shelves and in libraries, we take these "points" and arrange them on "planes", often according to typical, spatial or spectral aspects of the points

how can we port these evolved behaviors to digital systems?

eg: a book has words and pictures (lingual, graphical); was published, and perhaps revised (temporal); may have references or sources (relational; can be reduced to a set of topics or categories (typical); has a cover, pages and type in certain colors/shapes (spectral, spatial)

physical media seems to have seven main roots:
- lingual
- graphical
- temporal
- relational
- typical
- spectral
- spatial

these roots help us understand, find, sort, classify, compare and group media

digital media should be no different

Whether push and pull, inverse kinematics, space-conforming blobs, or something else entirely— there are whole realms of interfaces to explore when you start thinking outside the (nested) box

This idea would be hard to make in html, but very easy once you start thinking in terms of constraints

Think of each website you visit as a point along a timeline, then if you click on a point it gets pulled out and displays the past/future context surrounding it: https://t.co/iXH7wHxkQw

Even simple constraints: designing interfaces around push/pull instead of nested hierarchies of rectangles can unlock new ideas

Like, imagine a timeline (e.g. browser history) where as you zoom out, the points squish together and you start to see larger overall trends https://t.co/3RoXksROyX
Constraints open up all kinds of interesting unexplored design-spaces— like what if you put buttons and data floating around space-conforming blobs? https://t.co/G1QUAeBqcs

By extending tags, you get all of the fields from the extended tag.

LinkedIn and Twitter pipeline tagged nodes set the default values for stage and medium fields. So they aren’t strictly necessary, but are really convenient! Means I don't have to set the values each time. https://t.co/WZVgptJ7CI

In Tana, Supertags are a form of a type system, and you can extend one tag with another.

So imagine I have three tags: #pipeline, which is extended by #twitter pipeline, and #linkedin pipeline.

A simple query for #pipeline pulls all of these, and then I group by status. https://t.co/DrJ2mw0t6L

@dangoor @Mappletons @tana_inc @cortexfutura Yup! One thing you can do is add a tag, use it for weeks, and then create a table out of that tag and add new columns to it that will be added to all past instances of the tag. Pretty cool way to update your system over time!

@sgbeal @svoisen Thanks, makes sense!

@sgbeal @svoisen And in general, curious if you have any other thoughts on the feasibility of having a fast SQLite build talking to the regular non-OPFS FSAccess API? (It seems not possible given the current web APIs but I’m trying to understand how fundamental the limitations are…)

@sgbeal @svoisen Thanks, v helpful! 
I’m curious, what kinds of locks or atomic writes does SQLite require from the FS? Given that SQLite itself manages concurrent access, my hope would be you don’t need too much from the FS?

@timbray @svoisen Seems similar to what desktop apps have to deal with when saving to files, right? Could have been manually edited? (I believe there are costs there but maybe they are not prohibitively large..?)

Ok more learnings in this branch of the thread via @svoisen! My tentative takeaway is that extending this to user-visible files is hard because exclusive write locks on files is a major part of the design for these fast random access file APIs https://t.co/WmTWL09uku

@svoisen @gordonbrander The exclusive write access thing may be more of an insurmountable issue though. Sounds like security and correctness issues that might be hard to overcome in the general FileSystemAccess context https://t.co/aE4SQX603e

@svoisen @gordonbrander Aha, thank you, these docs seem super relevant!

One tidbit I noticed: the merging doc says “It would be relatively simple to also add this change to the rest of FSA.”, referencing the duplex stream API that seems to be what landed in OPFS. so maybe there is some hope….?

I do wonder if there are different points avail in the tradeoff space of perf + user-visible files. I don’t wanna naively imply it would be easy in any sense but the goal seems incredibly worthwhile to me if it’s achievable.
Per some sleuthing with help from @gordonbrander, seems like exclusive write access locks help with performance, and may be a motivation for the OPFS restriction… https://t.co/Y4gsy8Xhzi
@gordonbrander Aha I guess this maybe explains why exclusive write locks are valuable. https://t.co/qajsxSPg32

@gordonbrander Hmm yeah I’m reaching limits of my FS knowledge here… need to learn more what “exclusive access” means. As one datapoint I think SQLite is designed to have multiple connections sharing a single file? (No write concurrency allowed but will avoid data corruption)

@gordonbrander Yeah fair point. I guess if a browser chooses to implement OPFS in a way that you can reasonably find the backing directory, then it basically approximates  that experience

https://t.co/ynpmmlIurt
@gordonbrander I’m definitely very naive about the complexity of this API area but I’m just so curious to learn what the specific challenges are!!

@gordonbrander Yeah that matches my understanding. Although it’s not obvious to me what exactly about these more flexible APIs would cause problems with user-facing files. the Access Handle spec just says that’s “not currently considered”: https://t.co/htg9rK8PX2

@gordonbrander Yeah this all makes sense. But also I know they’re thinking through these problems already for the new APIs that do talk to the user FS. so I wonder what additional problems are caused by these fast FS access handle APIs
Hmm I guess purely speculating here, I can imagine why expanding the surface area that a browser has with the device local FS (in perpetuity, including future file systems) could be scary 🤔

Also curious if anyone knows what the right way is to advocate for these kinds of changes beyond commenting on a random github issue. I've never explored how to nudge web standards in a different direction but this particular issue feels really important!! 8/

I wonder if it's not considered valuable enough to prioritize, or if it's somehow really hard to implement. The opaqueness of OPFS ("it could be backed by anything, user can't see") does seem to offer implementers a lot of latitude.

Would be curious if anyone has guesses...

So what's the catch then?

This SQLite build will be backed by the "origin private file system" (OPFS) which means these "files" aren't visible to the user.

This is because the performant FS APIs are only available inside OPFS. 4/ https://t.co/cnoA8WuzBR

@simonw @pfrazee bringing this back to the broader point, this is why I _really_ think discussions about web3 work backwards from the goal to interesting mechanisms for achieving it. There's more out there than PoW blockchains, which seem like one of the worst possible solutions to me.
@simonw @pfrazee This is also a really interesting version to think about: https://t.co/pxFyVTVHDO
@simonw @pfrazee Yeah, there are a good number of takes on it. I think they do a really bad job of explaining it, but Holo is operating on this type of model: https://t.co/6vL0coDvGi

@simonw @pfrazee Yeah, I don't think the current blockchains are the right way forward. There are other systems that have much more useful models I think - mutual credit for example allows you to build in significant reputational damage such that acting badly is more costly than being truthful.

@simonw @pfrazee Doesn't seem like it _has_ to be all or nothing. If your bank stole money for example, you'd escape to the courts. I don't think a multi-tiered system is antithetical to providing an alternative mechanism for certain commitments.
@simonw @pfrazee fwiw, I would expect much lower stakes commitments to be the norm for a long time and maybe eventually it finds its way into bigger things, but it may very well never do so.

@simonw @pfrazee Yeah, I mention in one of the footnotes that building in escapes to handle extenuating circumstances would definitely be needed. I agree that full automation would be quite bad without significant changes at nearly every level. I would definitely treat that as an extreme view.

@simonw @pfrazee If you believe that scenario is likely, then presumably you wouldn't choose to be a part of the contract to begin with. Same problem exists regardless of smart contracts and it seems like default arbitration by an accepted third party would be better than going to the courts.

@jonathoda @sc13ts As an example, notion is far from a miracle but allowed people to customize on an axis they didn’t previously have access to (embedded data models). That created a ton of power for people and there’s now an entire portion of YouTube devoted to workflows that it enables.
@jonathoda @sc13ts It wouldn’t surprise me if it was a combination of things that exist that we just haven’t tried yet though. Not sure it’s in the category of we need a whole new science.
@jonathoda @sc13ts I agree that it’s not category theory or probably logic. That’d be like saying you first need to know maxwell’s equations to plug a lamp into a different socket.

@jonathoda @sc13ts I don’t think it has to be a miracle though. If you want to be able to turn your home into a spaceship you need a miracle, but there are a lot of useful points before then that I think would capture the vast majority of what people would do and are much simpler to achieve

@jonathoda @sc13ts Most of the people working on this find the legos themselves the interesting part, but stopping there ensures you’ll only have something for the people who want to build their own house with their own hands.

@jonathoda @sc13ts The hard, lonely, path blazing part is to find something that is compositional enough to function the way things to do in the physical world. Something with a very gradual ramp. Then you have to build a completely orthogonal product using it. You need the legos and the castle.

@jonathoda @sc13ts The big thing is that I’m not just building the whole house from scratch. I’m taking some part of it and making it work better for me and everything I already have in the house is something I can use to accomplish that. It’s a fully built Lego set, but it’s still Lego
@jonathoda @sc13ts Most people just buy furniture to put into their homes, but even that is a ton of customization. Some go on to build exactly what they want. Others just paint a thing.

@jonathoda @sc13ts Give people a thing they already know how to use and understand the value of and then give them the ability to customize it as much or as little as they want. It’s amazing what they’ll do with it. People love to make things their own and some will go to crazy lengths to do so
@jonathoda @sc13ts Accepting that very very few people will make it to the extreme and that for different things they may make it to totally different points along the way.

@jonathoda @sc13ts I personally think it’s probably the wrong goal to focus on making “programming” more widespread. Instead I’d think of a spectrum of customization - from using an app as is, to the very far end of make my own custom thing. The goal would be to let people move along that spectrum

These reflections have turned into important guiding principles when designing @sanedotfyi. For ex, our interface only has the essentials you need to write and collect docs on browser. This makes it easier to get into a meditative thinking state, and get zoned into a project. 6/6

But when you remove as many distractions as possible, and stop obsessing over productivity goals, you’re also removing a lot of the constraints and boundaries that are often making it hard to focus and think creatively! 5/6
It’s increasingly difficult to practice meditative thinking because of the incessant, overflow of information surrounding us at any given moment. 4/6
For example, lingering on a sentence while reading a book to take the time to explore what associations, ideas, or feelings might arise from it. 3/6
For me, meditative thinking is really about savouring the thought, idea, word, or whatever you’re engaging with — rather than attempting to process it as quickly as possible. 2/6

A term we’ve used a lot building Sane is ‘meditative thinking’. By meditative thinking we refer to a kind of flow state that you can get to when you really slow down, forget about productivity, and think about a topic from a perspective of wander. 1/6

@davidstafford @xuenay @ArtirKel For what it's worth, I think most modern CS papers are scams; there's probably a much smaller percentage of real papers today than in 1970, so it's not like I am super shocked.

@davidstafford @xuenay @ArtirKel I understand that everyone at the time thought it was real and was a revolutionary leap -- I did too when I was in school, because I was taught that it was. But a dispassionate, distant, objective assessment shows no such thing.

@davidstafford @xuenay @ArtirKel Sorry but I think time has shown that this "revolutionary leap" statement was clearly false -- it already was clearly false by the 1990s -- and I don't know why you give it so much credit.
@davidstafford @xuenay @ArtirKel which as far as I can tell is clearly false. It was just normal at the time -- the field was in full scam mode.

@davidstafford @xuenay @ArtirKel In that paragraph he's basically saying the paper was a scam, but that this was normal at the time. And he's saying this *20 years later*, at the time I was an undergrad and learned about the system! This is *very* different from the statement that he never said it was real,

@davidstafford @xuenay @ArtirKel I mean, was the field giving out doctorates and Stanford professorships for works of fiction? That seems to be the claim if everyone was supposed to understand it was a concept and not a real system. So I don't understand the claim. But again, I was not there.

@davidstafford @xuenay @ArtirKel Didn't he? This claim sounds revisionist to me (I was certainly *taught* that it had been a working system). Note that the OP of this thread also presumes it worked. The language of his thesis sure seems to claim it is a thing: https://t.co/cQfoIyc3nv
@xuenay @ArtirKel Also the dog *totally* ate my homework.

@xuenay @ArtirKel The story I was told as an undergrad (early 1990s) was that the running version that was demoed that generated all this great stuff was modified in a REPL and had symbol patches all over the place etc and those changes never got converted back to the source code thus were lost.
@xuenay @ArtirKel If it was real, you would have expected other better things to happen in the subsequent say 30 years.

@xuenay @ArtirKel Except as far as I ever heard, nobody was ever able to run SHRDLU in a state where it would work as well as implied in the paper, and neither was anything after ever able to do that, and these facts raise a lot of questions.

Many thanks to Daniel for leading Lexica's seed round. And to AI Grant for also accepting us into their fantastic program. 

I'm very much looking forward to working with these exceptionally bright people for years to come!

Finally, if the idea of building AI-first creative tool deeply excites you, please do reach out! Our team is small – but we're fiercely passionate about building thoughtful creative tools, and I'd love for us to work together.

The discourse around AI in creative fields often overlooks the fact that the proper tools can give us significantly *more* agency – not less. 

Lexica is an attempt to create one of those tools – and hopefully enable new mediums of expression and entertainment in the process.

I'm excited to announce Lexica's $5M seed round led by Daniel Gross and Nat Friedman via AI Grant

[5/5, end]

Re: my threat-assessment of mpox, I think we're in a forest full of dry underbrush, but *this particular* lightning bolt won't burn us all. Still fragile, something something black swans, prepare not predict. But *this* bolt: low R0, very low fatality, curve bent ~1mo ago: [4/5] https://t.co/gogGgrsdr1

They stopped vaxxing public for smallpox in 70s coz the eradication campaign worked + ring-vax had nasty side effects. Jynneos is safe(r); only side-effect I got was more hunger that day. If you're born >1972 & it's free for your demographic, I think the cost-benefit works! [3/5]

(In case you weren't aware, the vaccines they're distributing for the new monkeypox weren't designed for or based off mpox. They were for smallpox. It's the same vax. Thankfully, small-, monkey-, and cow- all give decent cross-immunity. {chickenpox is not a true poxvirus.}) [2/5]

Got my smallpox vax! Even if you think mpox is low-threat (and I do) I still recommend a pox vax. Since international relations are crumbling & biotech's getting cheaper, I expect in my lifetime *someone* will try bringing back one of history's deadliest viruses. [1/5] https://t.co/bWeO9nywiE

I’m doing this with my personal savings, but the goal is that as startupy grows and reaches sustainability, we will take a portion of membership proceeds and route them back to the community in the form of thinking microgrants.

$2,000 is not a ton of money, but I’m hoping it will give someone out there the push they need to fall down a deep, intellectually rich rabbit hole and take the long view instead of being dragged into short term games.

The only way to do great work in any field is to find time to consider the large questions, read, and think. But having time to think is a luxury. That feeling hasn’t left me and I want to pay it forward.

In 2019, I was in the lucky position that I had spare time and decided to allocate more of that time to reading, writing a newsletter, and exploring my interests. In hindsight, that was one of the best career decision I ever made.

I’m offering 5 grants of $2,000 for people to go think about anything they want.

- Birth: It works
- Life: Updated to be more robust, faster
- Death: It’s use-case is covered by something new, so it can be killed

Whimsical features are overrated. Imagine… You walk into a building at ground level, get on an elevator, press the button for the 3rd floor… then the car goes *zing* up to the 5th floor before springing back two floors and wobbling a bit before the doors open. So whimsical. 😒 https://t.co/z8T8P9rg9i

I don’t want much whimsy in my software either, since I don’t want apps that call attention to themselves. The more frequently I use a feature, the less likely I want anything about it to be whimsical.

I’ve given up on notes apps. On my MacBook, I have a single text file in @bbedit. It’s always open. I draft almost all my text in this file, including these tweets. Later on, if I need to find something I’ve written, I know exactly where to look and search.

Great apps offer minimal controls placed in a straightforwardly visible location. Just enough to help me get the job done easily. So many apps have features that get in the way without yielding much benefit.
I don’t want a lot of user interface in my apps. The best software gets out of the way.

@phokarlsson ...DuoLingo keeps tossing the ability to explore freely in favor of one pre-determined path that their A/B tests showed worked for a plurality? majority? of users.

Their latest test is literally that: one path, one sequence of steps, rather than being able to self-direct a bit.

@phokarlsson We've seen this difference lately in a big way with Stable Diffusion in contrast to what came before it.

So then the question becomes: how do we ensure more of our software is open-ended, or creates open-ended systems for people to explore, in the future?

@phokarlsson Fascinating discourse, thanks for sharing!

This also relates to how our software works today — So much of today's software reduces possible uses to a tiny set of chosen paths, directed by companies' KPIs. Users aren't afforded the opportunity to explore.

@phokarlsson Yes, I draw on a series of prompts in my notes, especially when I sense low energy / curiosity / enthusiasm.
@phokarlsson (I just need to make sure that it's centered on the right motivation; if my motivations change, my "goals" need to as well.)

@phokarlsson It sounds more nebulous / less objective, but it causes me to start from my motivation each week, and to find the right thing ... as a result, it usually produces a higher cadence and higher quality work.

@phokarlsson That goal maintains intrinsic motivation for the work; it doesn’t replace it, instead, it asks what it is. It asks what I'm excited about sharing with people that week. 

The goal is more to ask the question every week, and let whatever comes of it happen.

@phokarlsson E.g.: I find great joy in publishing new things for people to have and enjoy. The goal is not to publish frequently, but to chase that joy... to create & publish things I’m excited about sharing with people each week.

@phokarlsson Or: A goal of 1 lab note / week creates misguided / hollow external pressure (rather than IM), and if work is taking longer, guilt.

Instead, if I know what my motivation is, I can make a goal that surfaces it.
The best goals surface intrinsic motivation rather than crowd it out.

"Parametric architecture" leans in this direction, but even when every element of one of those structures is unique, there's often a lingering feeling of sterility. I guess one gets the sense that those materials aren't even slightly malleable—the opposite of How Buildings Learn.

Like: sure, your walls are made of carbon nanotubules, but the grain of the surface isn't uniform and flat—it's constantly in subtle motion, roiling to catch and scatter the light. You can tile its surface geometry into new patterns every day, suited to each corner of the space…

C Alexander argues that one reason why people are instinctively drawn to traditional building materials is non-uniformity—every stone, board, and bit of plaster distinct, placed in context. Fun to imagine future materials (via home fab or nanotech) acquiring the same properties. https://t.co/m75HAEDXl9

@johnnulls What I mean is, if I enter a name—say Sherlock Holmes—in a block, that works very well in a list. If you zoom out into a grid with hundreds, what works best is some sort of avatar. After each lecture, participants discussed how they might apply these topics to their own organizations and communities. The collaborative Figjam files for each lecture are available on our site: https://t.co/yz7lckrAQ9

@idamantium shares her work on transformative experiences and reveals 4 key design components for community ritual design: risk, magic circle, structure, and transformation.
https://t.co/1hASLD3jCa

@tanisi_pooran introduces the idea of “foundational agreements”—documents that capture and memorialize both how an organization works and proposals for change. Agreements are one way to express values a self-managed system. 
https://t.co/1hJefQQ1Uy

@samspurlin asks participants to conceive of DAOs as an “operating system” and introduces a canvas to help orgs map assumptions, processes, and responsibilities baked into how they work.
https://t.co/fSFPJ8VC3c

@kvallier explores how credible neutrality is achieved—or not—in Web 2.0 platforms, and how DAOs might be able to avoid the contradictions posed by earlier tech stacks.
https://t.co/C9I5AHmc2a

@lkatfield goes deep on the philosophical roots of liberal neutrality that inform crypto’s idea of “credible neutrality,” popularized by @vitalikbuterin. DAOs can learn much from how societies past have chosen to reward specific perceptions of “goodness.”
https://t.co/WZmUMYiQVy

@incompleterules discusses the elephant in the room: DAOs as conflict, and why community values are key to the development of strong governance processes.
https://t.co/pkdmAbXjB1

@starodaj provides a detailed case study of municipal government and community coordination to solve local housing price issues. DAOs have much to learn from local government!
https://t.co/TQSRywY8eQ

@economic_lab outlines how political ideologies and policy environments shape corporate structure, and demonstrates these principles with a detailed case study on the evolution of the US electric coop sector. 
https://t.co/0xCD7RRPu2

@mensermk speaks from his deep experience with participatory budgeting, an area of deep relevance to DAO-driven capital allocation. ”Democracy is not about having a voice, it’s about sharing power and authority.”
https://t.co/YxTeO63xZO

@profmadison marries the study of knowledge commons with governance, in the context of data, public goods, and other resources.
https://t.co/6ZrDQv2nMZ

Pavel Kuchar argues it’s fruitful to consider markets as forms of knowledge commons and outlines some key design principles for collective choice. 
https://t.co/zac5q2J0Ad

@sohwng brings case studies of decentralized communities engaged in emergent rule formation. One takeaway: premature standardization can kill a community!
https://t.co/v5PSvy4YH0

Dana Brakman explores governance structures for nonprofits and how they arose through suspicion of elite philanthropy. She ends by discussing alternative legal forms for philanthropic DAOs. https://t.co/LkOyZhXLRU
@GrennanJill outlines how boards manage conflict, protect against activist investors, and set payout expectations & voting rights. https://t.co/oM0ZURulaM

Camille Canon gives us some guidelines for thinking about how governance models, rule making, and value distribution fit together in a coherent system—and how misalignments can make an org fragile. https://t.co/MDCfQpAnMU

This is why I’m so happy to finally have a local-first sync engine in Muse 2.0, now rolling out to the relatively large existing userbase.

This will be a chance to see how local-first performs in real world usage vs than research prototypes.

Since then the term “local-first” has spread in hacker communities but remains more of a research area + aspiration than a reality.

Induction is logic's traditional problem child: seeing only white swans is no guarantee all are white.

But deduction is just as bad, where to find absolute premises if not tautology? Don't claim math's certainty from rickety inputs like all swans are white or all men are mortal.

An opinionated diagram of the 3 main guesses in logic: deduction, induction & abduction. All 3 framed as just very broad patterns of conjecture, not infallible rules.

When making variable fonts, every key design of a glyph have to
• Have the same number of shapes, in the same order.
• Each shape has to have the same number of nodes, same Bézier handles and same order of nodes.

@pfrazee If I understand, schema negotiation is a way of allowing protocol to express what client MAY or MUST NOT ignore?

Protocol-client coevolution...

Specialization increases as ecosystem matures.

Overspecialized client-protocol relationships can become delicate and impractical.

Generic protocols can be resilient (email). But may also fail to adapt due to inability to evolve quickly. https://t.co/pgL0xzLBtd

“A protocol moves more slowly than a platform. After 30y, email is unencrypted; meanwhile WhatsApp went e2ee in a year. This isn’t a funding issue. If something is decentralized, it becomes difficult to change, and often remains stuck in time.” https://t.co/WqEks5WFkY

Protocol-client coupling

High coupling
Upside: can evolve rapidly together (essentially one meta-organism).
Downside: there can be only one client (essentially one meta-organism).

Low coupling.
Upside: can implement many clients.
Downside: core protocol slow/hard to evolve.
Protocol-client ecosystems are unstable. (All living systems are unstable.) My sense is by default, protocol-client wants to collapse toward https://t.co/EfRimmrtsL
